About this site

Mytabworks's projects, libraries, and all it's content was occasionally made during the pandemic lockdown which is started in mid march of 2020 and deploy in august 2020.

Almost 90.99% of the app was handmadely coded from scratch by the creator itself. the only components used in this site which is not done by the creator was the react-live, jszip, icons and tools images.

Reatable (not publish yet)

is a react dynamic table which displays rows of data. It is so light with catchy setting and cognitive design structure. reatable is not limited with it's design and it's features since most of it's aspects are cuztomizable so table's creativity is endless within its bootstrap.

Installation #

npm i reatable
Imports #

import { Table, TableContent, Pagination, Loader, usePagination, useSort, useFilter } from "reatable"
Getting Started #

it is the basic example for reatable.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name"
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name"
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age"
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",
        label: "Gender"
    },
]
const data = [
    {
        id: 1,
        fname: 'Drew',
        lname: 'Kai',
        age: '24',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 2,
        fname: 'Frankie',
        lname: 'Riley',
        age: '70',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 3,
        fname: 'Brook',
        lname: 'Mason',
        age: '38',
        gender: 'female',
    },
    {
        id: 4,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Emery',
        age: '31',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 5,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Bailey',
        age: '49',
        gender: 'female',
    },
];
#render(<Table columns={columns} data={data} />)

Table or TableContent setting className attribute will remove the default stylesheet in table to prevent conflict to the setted class.

Table property data must be an array of object that contains id or key to distinguish it from each other to prevent bugs.

Mutating Table Cell #

you can mutate the appearance and elements of table cell

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name"
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name"
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age"
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",
        label: "Gender",
        render: (gender, row, index) => (
            <span className={`badge badge-${gender === 'male' ? 'info' : 'danger'}`}>
                {gender}
            </span>
        )
    },
]
const data = [
    {
        id: 1,
        fname: 'Drew',
        lname: 'Kai',
        age: '24',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 2,
        fname: 'Frankie',
        lname: 'Riley',
        age: '70',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 3,
        fname: 'Brook',
        lname: 'Mason',
        age: '38',
        gender: 'female',
    },
    {
        id: 4,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Emery',
        age: '31',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 5,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Bailey',
        age: '49',
        gender: 'female',
    },
];
#render(<Table columns={columns} data={data} />)

Column Group #

you can group your table column headers.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
const columns = [
    { 
        label: "Human Data",
        columns: [
            {
                label: "Name",
                columns: [
                    {
                        dataIndex: "fname",
                        label: "First Name"
                    },
                    {
                        dataIndex: "lname",
                        label: "Last Name"
                    },
                ]
            },
            {
                dataIndex: "age",
                label: "Age"
            },
            { 
                label: "Gender",
                columns: [
                    {
                        dataIndex: "gender",
                        label: "Male",
                        render: (gender) => gender === "male" && "<span role="img">✔️</span>"
                    },
                    {
                        dataIndex: "gender",
                        label: "Female",
                        render: (gender) => gender === "female" && "<span role="img">✔️</span>"
                    },
                ]
            },
        ]
    },
]
const data = [
    {
        id: 1,
        fname: 'Drew',
        lname: 'Kai',
        age: '24',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 2,
        fname: 'Frankie',
        lname: 'Riley',
        age: '70',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 3,
        fname: 'Brook',
        lname: 'Mason',
        age: '38',
        gender: 'female',
    },
    {
        id: 4,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Emery',
        age: '31',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 5,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Bailey',
        age: '49',
        gender: 'female',
    },
];
#render(
    <Table columns={columns} data={data} />
)

Tip

you can group column headers as many group as you like.

Table property data must be an array of object that contains id or key to distinguish it from each other to prevent bugs.

Sortable Table #

it has built-in feature column sorting.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name",
        sortable: true,
        sortOrderDefault: 'desc'
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name",
        sortable: (a, b) => a.length - b.length,
        sortDirection: ["asc"]
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age",
        sortable: true,
        sortDirection: ["desc", "asc"]
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",

the column property sortable can be assign boolean that will be sorted by the built-in sorting algorithm of the component. or you can make your own algorithm by assigning function that compares the two argument.

built-in sorting algorithm is not applicable in asynchronous table.

Collapsible Table #

you can make a collapsible table.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name", 
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name"
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age",
        sortable: true,
        sortOrderDefault: 'asc'
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",
        label: "Gender"
    },
]
const data = [
    {
        id: 1,
        fname: 'Drew',
        lname: 'Kai',
        age: '24',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 2,
        fname: 'Frankie',
        lname: 'Riley',
        age: '70',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 3,
        fname: 'Brook',
        lname: 'Mason',
        age: '38',
        gender: 'female',
    },
    {
        id: 4,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Emery',
        age: '31',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 5,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Bailey',
        age: '49',
        gender: 'female',
    },
];
#render(
    <>
        <style>
            {`.row-collapsible tr[data-collapsible="true"] {
                cursor: pointer; 
            }`}
            {`.row-collapsible tr[data-collapsible="false"] { 
                background: rgba(0,0,0,0.05)
            }`}
        </style>
        <Table 
            className="n-table n-no-shadow row-collapsible" 
            columns={columns} 
            data={data}  
            collapsible={{
                render: (row) => (
                    <div style={{padding: "10px 20px"}}>
                    {`${row.fname} ${row.lname} is age below 50, that is why the row is collapsible base on the condition in collapseWhen`}
                    </div>
                ),
                collapseWhen: (row) => parseInt(row.age) < 50,
                collapseWhenClickRow: true,
                accordion: true,
                transition: {
                    duration: 100,
                    timingFunction: "ease-in"
                },
            }}
        />
    </>
)

Last Name

Collapsible Table Using Button #

you can make a collapsible table using button in columns render.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name",
        render: (fname, row, index, {collapsible, sort, page, filters}) => {
            const { collapsed, collapseHandler } = collapsible 
            return (
                <span className="d-flex flex-center-y">
                    {collapsible && (
                        <button 
                            className={`n-btn btn-caret mr-2${collapsed ? " active" : ""}`} 
                            onClick={collapseHandler} 
                        />  
                    )}
                    {fname}
                </span>
            )
        }
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name"
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age",
        sortable: true,
        sortOrderDefault: 'asc'
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",
        label: "Gender"
    },
]
const data = [
    {
        id: 1,
        fname: 'Drew',
        lname: 'Kai',
        age: '24',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 2,
        fname: 'Frankie',
        lname: 'Riley',
        age: '70',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 3,
        fname: 'Brook',
        lname: 'Mason',
        age: '38',
        gender: 'female',
    },
    {
        id: 4,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Emery',
        age: '31',
        gender: 'male',
    },
    {
        id: 5,
        fname: 'West',
        lname: 'Bailey',
        age: '49',
        gender: 'female',
    },
];
#render(
    <> 
        <Table 
            className="n-table n-no-shadow row-collapsible" 
            columns={columns} 
            data={data}  
            collapsible={{
                render: (row) => (
                    <div style={{padding: "10px 20px"}}>
                    {`${row.fname} ${row.lname} is age below 50, that is why the row is collapsible base on the condition in collapseWhen`}
                    </div>
                ),
                collapseWhen: (row) => parseInt(row.age) < 50,
            }}
        />
    </>
)

Table Filtration #

it has built-in feature column filtering.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name", 
        sortable: true,
        filterSearch: { label: "Search", like: "{search}%"}
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name",
        sortable: true,
        filters: [
            { label: "Starts with A", like: "a%" },
            { label: "Starts with B", like: "b%" },
            { label: "Ends with Y", like: "%y" },
            { label: "Has C", like: "%c%" }
        ],
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age", 
        sortable: true,
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",
        label: "Gender",  
        filters: [
            { label: "Male", like: "male" },
            { label: "Female", like: "female" }
        ],
        filterMultiple: false
    },
]

built-in filtering algorithm is not applicable in asynchronous table.

Asynchronous Table #

you can make asynchronous table.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name", 
        sortable: true,
        filterSearch: { label: "Search", like: "{search}%"}
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name",
        sortable: true,
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age",
        sortable: true,
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",
        label: "Gender", 
        filters: [
            { label: "Male", like: "male" },
            { label: "Female", like: "female" }
        ],
        filterMultiple: false
    },
]
const AsyncTable = () => {
    const [response, setResponse] = React.useState({data: [], rowsCount: 0})
    const [changes, setChanges] = React.useState(null)
    React.useEffect(() => {
        if(!changes) return
        
        const controller = new AbortController()
        fetch("/human/data", {
            signal: controller.signal,
            method: "GET", 
            headers: {
                "Content-Type": "application/json"
            },
            body: {
                sortOrderBy: changes.sort.orderBy,
                sortOrder: changes.sort.order,
                currentPage: changes.pagination.currentPage,
                pageSize: changes.pagination.pageSize,
                filters: changes.filters,
            } 
        })
        .then((response) => {
            if(response.status === 200) {
                return response.json() 
            } else {
                response.error()
            }
        }).then((result) => {
            setResponse({
                data: result.data,
                rowsCount: result.rowsCount
            })
        })
        .catch((error) => console.error(error))
        return () => controller.abort()
    }, [changes])
    const handleChange = React.useCallback((e) => { 
        setChanges(e)
    }, [])
    return (
        <Table 
            className="n-table n-no-shadow sortable-table" 
            columns={columns} 
            data={response.data} 
            pagination={{
                pageSize: 5,
                totalRows: response.rowsCount
            }} 
            asynchronous
            onChange={handleChange} 
        />
    )
}
#render(<AsyncTable />)

Customizable Pagination Component #

you can customize pagination container and list and still using the Pagination components algorithm.

import React from "react";
import { Table, TableContent, Pagination } from "reatable";
import data from "human-data.json";
import {columns, data} from "human-data"; 
const PaginationContainer = ({ children }) => (
    <ul className="n-nav n-nav-flated n-no-hover">
        {children}
    </ul>
)
const PaginationList = ({ children, active, disabled, onClick }) => ( 
    <a 
       className={`n-nav-link${active 
            ? " active" 
            : disabled 
            ? " disabled" 
            : ""}`
       }
       href="#" 
       onClick={onClick}>
        {children}
    </a> 
)
#render(
    <Table  
        columns={columns} 
        data={data} 
        pagination={{
            pageSize: 5
        }}>
        <div className="overflow-x-auto">
            <TableContent className="n-table n-no-shadow sortable-table" />
            <div className="d-flex flex-end-x">
                <Pagination 
                    prevLabel="〈"
                    nextLabel="〉"
                    as={{
                        Container: PaginationContainer,
                        List: PaginationList
                    }} 
                />
            </div>
        </div>
    </Table>
)

Create Your Own Pagination #

if you don't like the overall Pagination component model, then you can create your own by using usePagination.

import React from "react";
import { Table, TableContent, usePagination } from "reatable";
import {columns, data} from "human-data"; 
const CustomPagination = () => {
    const { allowPagination, totalPages, page, setPage } = usePagination();
    return allowPagination && (
        <nav className="n-nav">
            {Array.from(new Int32Array(totalPages)).map((v, index) => {
                const pageNumber = index + 1
                return (
                    <a key={index}
                        href="#" 
                        className={`n-nav-link${ 
                            pageNumber === page 
                            ? " active"  
                            : ""}`
                        }
                        onClick={(e) => {
                            e.preventDefault()
                            setPage(pageNumber)
                        }}>
                        {pageNumber}
                    </a>
                )
            })}
        </nav>
    )
}
#render(
    <Table  
        columns={columns} 
        data={data} 
        pagination={{
            pageSize: 10
        }}>
        <div className="overflow-x-auto">  
            <TableContent className="n-table n-no-shadow sortable-table" />
            <div className="d-flex flex-end-x">
                <CustomPagination />
            </div>
        </div>
    </Table>
)

Changable Page Size #

there is no built-in component for page size changer but you can make your own by adding a few lines of code.

import React from "react";
import { Table, TableContent, Pagination } from "reatable";
import {columns, data} from "human-data"; 
const TableWrapper = () => {
    const [pagesize, setPagesize] = React.useState(5)
    const showStyle = {
        borderRadius: "2px",
        padding: "5px 10px",
        marginBottom: "16px"
    }
    const sizeSelectionStyle = {
        ...showStyle, 
        borderColor: '#f0f0f0'
    }
    return (
        <Table  
            columns={columns} 
            data={data} 
            pagination={{
                pageSize: pagesize
            }}>
            <div className="overflow-x-auto">
                <TableContent className="n-table n-no-shadow sortable-table" />
                <div className="d-flex flex-spb-x">
                    <div className="d-flex">
                        <span style={showStyle}>show</span>
                        <select value={pagesize} 
                            onChange={({target}) => setPagesize(parseInt(target.value)) }
                            style={sizeSelectionStyle}>
                            <option value="5">5</option>
                            <option value="10">10</option>
                            <option value="15">15</option>
                            <option value="20">20</option>
                        </select>
                    </div>
                    <Pagination /> 
                </div>
            </div>
        </Table>
    )
}
#render(<TableWrapper />)

Create Filter By First Letters #

you can do all you want on filtering by using hook useFilter, this is just one of many things that you can do.

import React from "react";
import { Table, TableContent, Pagination, useFilter } from "reatable";
import { data } from "human-data"; 
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name",  
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name",
        sortable: true,
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age", 
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",
        label: "Gender",
        filters: [
            { label: "Male", like: "male" },
            { label: "Female", like: "female" }
        ],
        filterMultiple: false,
    },
]
const Alphabet = [ 
    { label: "A", like: "a%" }, 
    { label: "B", like: "b%" },
    { label: "C", like: "c%" },
    { label: "D", like: "d%" },
    { label: "E", like: "e%" },
    { label: "F", like: "f%" },
    { label: "G", like: "g%" },
    { label: "H", like: "h%" }, 
    { label: "I", like: "i%" }, 
    { label: "J", like: "j%" },
    { label: "K", like: "k%" },
    { label: "L", like: "l%" },
    { label: "M", like: "m%" },
    { label: "N", like: "n%" },
    { label: "O", like: "o%" },
    { label: "P", like: "p%" },
    { label: "Q", like: "q%" },
    { label: "R", like: "r%" },
    { label: "S", like: "s%" },
    { label: "T", like: "t%" },
    { label: "U", like: "u%" },
    { label: "V", like: "v%" },
    { label: "W", like: "w%" },
    { label: "X", like: "x%" },
    { label: "Y", like: "y%" },
    { label: "Z", like: "z%" },
]
const CustomFilterAlphabet = () => {
    const [dataIndex, setDataIndex] = React.useState("fname")
    const { 
        // filterable, 
        // filters, 
        // filterMultiple, 
        // filterSearch,
        filterState,
        setFilter 
    } = useFilter(dataIndex);
    const dataIndexCurrentFilter = filterState.find(each => { 
        return each.dataIndex === dataIndex
    })
    
    return (
        <div className="d-flex flex-center-y mb-3"> 
            <div className="custom-filter">
                <span className="filter-label">Filter By:</span>
                <select
                    className="filter-form" 
                    value={dataIndex} 
                    onChange={({target}) => setDataIndex(target.value)}>
                    <option value="fname">First Name</option>
                    <option value="lname">Last Name</option> 
                </select>    
                <button 
                    className="filter-form"
                    onClick={() => setFilter(() => [])}>
                    Reset
                </button> 
            </div>  
            <ul className="custom-letter-filter">
                {Alphabet.map((each) => (
                        <li key={each.label} 
                            className={
                                dataIndexCurrentFilter && 
                                dataIndexCurrentFilter
                                    .value
                                    .includes(each.like) 
                                ? " active"  
                                : "" }>
                            <a  href="#" 
                                onClick={(e) => {
                                    e.preventDefault()
                                    setFilter((current) => {  
                                        const update = dataIndexCurrentFilter 
                                                            || { dataIndex, value: [] } 
                                        const isAlreadyActive = update.value.includes(each.like)
                                        update.value = isAlreadyActive
                                                ? update.value.filter(like => like !== each.like)
                                                : [...update.value, each.like]
                                        return update.value.length  
                                            ? [...current, update]
                                            : current.filter(fltr => fltr.dataIndex !== dataIndex)
                                    })
                                }}>
                            {each.label}
                            </a>
                        </li>
                    )
                )}
            </ul> 
        </div>
    )
}
const showStyle = {
    borderRadius: "2px",
    padding: "4px 10px",
    marginBottom: "16px"
}
const sizeSelectionStyle = {
    ...showStyle, 
    borderColor: '#f0f0f0'
}
const TableWrapper = () => {
    const [pagesize, setPagesize] = React.useState(5)
    return (
        <Table  
            columns={columns} 
            data={data} 
            pagination={{
                pageSize: pagesize
            }}>
            <div className="overflow-x-auto">
                <CustomFilterAlphabet />  
                <TableContent className="n-table n-no-shadow sortable-table" />
                <div className="d-flex flex-spb-x">
                    <div className="d-flex">
                        <span style={showStyle}>show</span>
                        <select value={pagesize} 
                            onChange={({target}) => setPagesize(parseInt(target.value)) }
                            style={sizeSelectionStyle}>
                            <option value="5">5</option>
                            <option value="10">10</option>
                            <option value="15">15</option>
                            <option value="20">20</option>
                        </select>
                    </div>
                    <Pagination /> 
                </div>
            </div>
        </Table>
    )
}
#render(<TableWrapper />)

Create Filter By Search #

filter by search is so typical in dynamic table. this is just the idea to create greater things.

import React from "react";
import { Table, TableContent, Pagination, useFilter } from "reatable";
import { data } from "human-data"; 
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: "fname",
        label: "First Name", 
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "lname",
        label: "Last Name",
        sortable: true, 
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "age",
        label: "Age", 
    },
    {
        dataIndex: "gender",
        label: "Gender",
        filters: [
            { label: "Male", like: "male" },
            { label: "Female", like: "female" }
        ],
        filterMultiple: false,
    },
] 
const CustomFilterBySearch = () => {
    const [dataIndex, setDataIndex] = React.useState("fname") 
    const { 
        // filterable, 
        // filters, 
        // filterMultiple, 
        // filterSearch,
        filterState,
        setFilter 
    } = useFilter(dataIndex);
    const dataIndexCurrentFilter = filterState.find(each => { 
        return each.dataIndex === dataIndex
    })
    return ( 
        <div key={dataIndex} className="custom-filter mb-3"> 
                <span className="filter-label">Filter By:</span> 
            <select
                className="filter-form" 
                value={dataIndex} 
                onChange={({target}) => {
                    setDataIndex(target.value)
                    setFilter((current) => current.filter((fltr) => fltr.dataIndex !== dataIndex))
                }}>
                <option value="fname">First Name</option>
                <option value="lname">Last Name</option> 
            </select>    
            <input 
                className="filter-form"
                placeholder="search..."
                value={dataIndexCurrentFilter 
                    ? dataIndexCurrentFilter.value[0].replace(/%/g, "")
                    : ""}
                onChange={({target}) => {
                    const value = target.value 
                    setFilter((current) => { 
                        const update = dataIndexCurrentFilter || { dataIndex, value: []}
                        update.value = [`${value}%`]
                        return value.length 
                            ? [...current, update]
                            : current.filter((fltr) => fltr.dataIndex !== dataIndex) 
                    })
                }} 
            /> 
            <button 
                className="filter-form"
                onClick={() => setFilter(() => [])}>
                Reset
            </button> 
        </div>  
    )
}
const showStyle = {
    borderRadius: "2px",
    padding: "4px 10px",
    marginBottom: "16px"
}
const sizeSelectionStyle = {
    ...showStyle, 
    borderColor: '#f0f0f0'
}
const TableWrapper = () => {
    const [pagesize, setPagesize] = React.useState(5)
    return (
        <Table  
            columns={columns} 
            data={data} 
            pagination={{
                pageSize: pagesize
            }}>
            <div className="overflow-x-auto">
                <div className="d-flex flex-spb-x"> 
                    <CustomFilterBySearch />
                    <Pagination /> 
                </div>
                <TableContent className="n-table n-no-shadow sortable-table" />
                <div className="d-flex flex-spb-x"> 
                    <div className="d-flex"> 
                        <span style={showStyle}>show</span>
                        <select value={pagesize} 
                            onChange={({target}) => setPagesize(parseInt(target.value)) }
                            style={sizeSelectionStyle}>
                            <option value="5">5</option>
                            <option value="10">10</option>
                            <option value="15">15</option>
                            <option value="20">20</option>
                        </select>
                    </div>
                    <Pagination /> 
                </div>
            </div>
        </Table>
    )
}
#render(<TableWrapper />)

Customize TableContent Row & Cell #

you can customize and create your own features on the table row(tr) and cell(td) in your own perspective, design and functionalities by using useColumn hooks, you can get your column settings you entered in the Table property columns. the customize cell example is editable and it is just one of many features you can create.

import React from "react";
import { Table, TableContent, Pagination, useColumn } from "reatable";
import { data } from "human-data"; 
const columns = [
    {
        dataIndex: 'fname',
        label: 'First Name',
        sortable: true,
        filterSearch: { label: 'Search', like: '{search}%' },
    },
    {
        dataIndex: 'lname',
        label: 'Last Name',
        editable: true, // you can create your own feature like this and use the useColumn to get this settings
    },
    {
        dataIndex: 'age',
        label: 'Age',
        sortable: true,
    },
    {
        dataIndex: 'gender',
        label: 'Gender',
        filters: [
            { label: 'Male', like: 'male' },
            { label: 'Female', like: 'female' },
        ],
        filterMultiple: false,
    },
];
const TableRow = ({ row, children, ...props}) => (
    <tr
        className={`my-class${props['aria-expanded'] ? ' collapsed' : ''}`}
        {...props}
    >
        {children}
    </tr>
);
const EditableTableCell = ({ row, dataIndex, children, ...props}) => {
    const column = useColumn(dataIndex)  
    const [isEditMode, setEditMode] = React.useState(false)
    const [value, setValue] = React.useState(children)
    const handleDouble = (e) => {
        e.preventDefault()
        setEditMode(true)
    }
    const handleBlur = () => setEditMode(false)
    const handleChange = ({target}) => setValue(target.value)
    return (
        <td
            className={`your-class${props['data-sorted'] ? ' sorted' : ''}`}
            onDoubleClick={handleDouble}
            {...props}
        >
            {column.editable && isEditMode ? (
                <input 
                    autoFocus
                    value={value} 
                    onBlur={handleBlur} 
                    onChange={handleChange}
                    style={{
                        display: "inline",
                        border: 0
                    }} 
                /> 
            ) : (
                <span>{value}</span>
            )}
        </td>
    );
}
#render(
    <Table  
        columns={columns} 
        data={data} 
        pagination={{
            pageSize: 5
        }}>
        <div className="overflow-x-auto">  
            <TableContent 
                as={{
                    Row: TableRow,
                    Cell: EditableTableCell
                }} 
                className="n-table n-no-shadow sortable-table" 
            />
            <div className="d-flex flex-end-x"> 
                <Pagination /> 
            </div>
        </div>
    </Table>
)

Customize TableContent Empty Data #

if you don't like the given empty data design you can make your own.

import React from "react";
import { Table, TableContent } from "reatable";
import { columns } from "human-data"; 
const exampledata = []
const EmptyData = ({ colSpan }) => (
    <tr className="myclass" >
       <td colSpan={colSpan}>
            <center>Empty Data....</center>
       </td>
    </tr>
);  
#render(
    <Table  
        columns={columns} 
        data={exampledata}>
        <div className="overflow-x-auto">   
            <TableContent 
                as={{
                    Empty: EmptyData, 
                }} 
                className="n-table n-no-shadow" 
            />
        </div>
    </Table>
)

Customize TableContent Column Header #

it is just a mediocre example on how you create a column header with sortable. it is just an idea for you to create greater header.

import React from "react";
import { Table, TableContent, Pagination, useSort, useFilter } from "reatable";
import { columns, data } from "human-data"; 
const ColumnHeader = ({ label, dataIndex, ...rest }) => {
	const { sortable, sortOrder, handleSort } = useSort(dataIndex);
	const { filterable } = useFilter(dataIndex);
    return (
        <th 
            {...rest}
            data-sortable={sortable}
            data-sort-order={sortable ? sortOrder || 'none' : undefined}
            style={{backgroundColor: "#00BCD4"}}
        > 
            {sortable ? (
                <span className='rt-sortable' onClick={handleSort}>
                    {label}
                    <i className='rt-sort-icon' />
                </span>
            ) : (
                label
            )}  
        </th>
    );
};
#render(
    <Table  
        columns={columns} 
        data={data} 
        pagination={{
            pageSize: 5
        }}>
        <div className="overflow-x-auto">   
            <TableContent 
                as={{
                    Column: ColumnHeader, 
                }} 
                className="n-table n-no-shadow" 
            />
            <div className="d-flex flex-end-x"> 
                <Pagination /> 
            </div>
        </div>
    </Table>
)

Passing A Row Data On Modal #

it is an idea on how to pass a data on modal, since modal is commonly use to handle changes in table.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable";
import { Modal } from "modal";
import { data } from "human-data";  
const TableWrapper = () => {
    const [modalData, setModalData] = React.useState(false)
    const columns = React.useMemo(() => [
        {
            dataIndex: 'fname',
            label: 'First Name',
            sortable: true,
            filterSearch: { label: 'Search', like: '{search}%' },
        },
        {
            dataIndex: 'lname',
            label: 'Last Name',
        },
        {
            dataIndex: 'age',
            label: 'Age',
            sortable: true,
        },
        {
            dataIndex: 'gender',
            label: 'Gender',
            filters: [
                { label: 'Male', like: 'male' },
                { label: 'Female', like: 'female' },
            ],
            filterMultiple: false,
        },
        {
            dataIndex: 'id',
            label: 'Action',
            render: (id, row, index) => {
                const handleClick = () => setModalData(row)
                return (
                    <button 
                        className="n-btn n-btn-xs"
                        onClick={handleClick}
                    >
                        view
                    </button>
                )
            }
        },
    ], [])
    const handleClose = () => setModalData(false)
    return (
        <>
            <Table
                className="n-table n-no-shadow"
                columns={columns} 
                data={data} 
                pagination={{
                    pageSize: 5
                }}
            />  
            <Modal show={!!modalData} onHide={handleClose}>
                <Modal.Title onHide={handleClose}>Row Data</Modal.Title>                
                <Modal.Body> 
                    <p><b>ID</b>: {modalData.id}</p>
                    <p><b>First Name</b>: {modalData.fname}</p>
                    <p><b>Last Name</b>: {modalData.lname}</p>
                    <p><b>Age</b>: {modalData.age}</p>
                    <p><b>Gender</b>: {modalData.gender}</p>
                </Modal.Body>
                <Modal.Footer>
                    <button
                        className="n-btn" 
                        onClick={handleClose}>
                        Close
                    </button> 
                </Modal.Footer>
            </Modal>
        </>
    )
}
#render(<TableWrapper />)

Table Selection #

it is an example to apply a selection on your table with sending multple data in modal.

import React from "react";
import { Table } from "reatable"; 
import { Modal } from "modal";
import { data } from "human-data";
const CustomCheckbox = (props) => (
    <input type="checkbox" className="n-form-control va-m mb-1" {...props} />
)
const TableWrapper = () => {
    const pageRows = 5
    const [show, setShow] = React.useState(false)
    const [selected, setSelected] = React.useState([])
    const columns = React.useMemo(() => [
        {
            dataIndex: "id",
            label: ({ data }) => (
                <CustomCheckbox  
                    id="master"
                    checked={selected.length === pageRows}
                    indeterminate="true"
                    onChange={e => {
                        const isChecked = e.target.checked
                        setSelected(isChecked ? [...data] : [])
                    }}
                /> 
            ),
            render: (id, row, index) => {
                return (
                    <CustomCheckbox
                        id={id}
                        checked={selected.some(each => each.id === id)}
                        onChange={e => {
                            const isChecked = e.target.checked
                            setSelected(current => {
                                return isChecked 
                                    ? [...current, row]
                                    : current.filter(each => each.id !== id) 
                            })
                        }}
                    />
                )
            }
        },
        {
            dataIndex: "fname",
            label: "First Name",
        },
        {
            dataIndex: "age",
            label: "Age", 
            sortable: true,
        },
        {
            dataIndex: "gender",
            label: "Gender",  
            filters: [
                { label: "Male", like: "male" },
                { label: "Female", like: "female" }
            ],
            filterMultiple: false
        },
    ], [selected, pageRows])
    const handleChange = React.useCallback(() => setSelected([]), [])
    const handleClose = () => setShow(false)
    return (
        <>  
            <button
                disabled={!selected.length}
                className="n-btn mb-3"
                children="view"
                onClick={() => setShow(!show)}
            />
            <Table 
                className="n-table n-no-shadow" 
                columns={columns} 
                data={data} 
                pagination={{
                    pageSize: pageRows
                }} 
                onChange={handleChange}
            />
            <Modal show={show} onHide={handleClose}>
                <Modal.Title onHide={handleClose}>Row Data</Modal.Title>                
                <Modal.Body> 
                    {selected.map(row => ( 
                        <div key={row.id} className="n-engrave-low mb-3">
                            <div className="p-3">
                                <h5>
                                    {`${row.fname} ${row.lname} profile`}
                                </h5>
                                <p><b>ID</b>: {row.id}</p>
                                <p><b>First Name</b>: {row.fname}</p>
                                <p><b>Last Name</b>: {row.lname}</p>
                                <p><b>Age</b>: {row.age}</p>
                                <p><b>Gender</b>: {row.gender}</p>
                            </div>
                        </div>
                    ))}
                </Modal.Body>
                <Modal.Footer>
                    <button
                        className="n-btn" 
                        onClick={handleClose}>
                        Close
                    </button> 
                </Modal.Footer>
            </Modal>
        </>
    )
}
#render(<TableWrapper />)

API

Table #

It is the table wrapper.

Property
Property
Type
Type
Default
Default
Description
Description
columnsobject[]-The settings of the table columns.
dataobject[]-The data of the table which is to be display.
classNamestring-The className of your table.
paginationobject-The setting of your pagination.
collapsibleobject-The setting of your expandable row.
asynchronousbooleanfalseTo determine if the table data will be requested when action is pagination, sort, and filters. Plus, The loader will be activated while waiting on the request.
onChangeReact.useCallback-It will be triggered when there is a action changes in the table like pagination, sort, and filters.
TableContent #

It is the table itself.

Property
Property
Type
Type
Default
Default
Description
Description
asobject-It is use to customize certain components without changing the main algorithm.
classNamestring-The className of your table.
Pagination #

It is the pagination.

Property
Property
Type
Type
Default
Default
Description
Description
asobject-It is use to customize certain components without changing the main algorithm.
classNamestringrt-paginationThe className of your pagination.
nextLabelstring | element'next'The label of the next button.
prevLabelstring | element'prev'The label of the prev button.
Loader #

It is the loader when the table is asynchronous.

Property
Property
Type
Type
Default
Default
Description
Description
childrenelement<div className="rt-loader"/>Your customize element loader.

Hooks

usePagination #

It is use to create your own component pagination.

Property
Property
Type
Type
Default
Default
Description
Description
const {
allowPagination,boolean-It use to determine if pagination will be display.
totalPages,boolean-It is the total pages of the pagination.
page,number-It is the number of the current page.
setPage,function-It is use to assign the current page in the table state.
} = usePagination()
useSort #

It is use to create your own component sort. it is useful in Table property as Column.

Property
Property
Type
Type
Default
Default
Description
Description
const {
sortable,boolean-It is use to determine if column is sortable.
sortOrder,'asc' | 'desc' | null-It is the state order currently the column is in.
handleSort,function-It is the sort handler that suppose to be assign in the certain element property onClick
} = useSort(
dataIndexstring-To get the column setting.
)
useFilter #

It is use to create your own component filteration.

Property
Property
Type
Type
Default
Default
Description
Description
const {
filterable,boolean-It is use to determine if column is filterable.
filters,object[]-It is the content you put in Table property columns
filterSearch,object-It is the content you put in Table property columns
filterMultiple,boolean-It is the content you put in Table property columns
filterState,object[ ]-It is the current state of the filters which had been applied.
setFilter,function-It is use to assign filters in the table state.
} = useFilter(
dataIndexstring-To get the column setting.
)
